subject: RE: [junit] Correct Use of assertEquals()
msgSnippet: Erik, Thanks for your help.  How do I set up option number two, if I have multiple strings within my object? Thanks, Luis ...
messageBody:
Erik,

Thanks for your help. How do I set up option number two, if I have multiple
strings within my object?

Thanks,
Luis


>From: "Erik Meade" <emeade@...>
>Reply-To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
>Subject: RE: [junit] Correct Use of assertEquals()
>Date: Fri, 9 Feb 2001 02:34:43 -0800
>
>Luis,
>
>If looks like you are passing com.reta.af.common.viewfinder.View into
>the assertEquals. When testing for equality the method:
>
>public boolean equals(Object object)
>
>is called. If you do not override this method then the default
>implementation from the super class (often java.lang.Object) is used.
>The default equals method checks to see if the objects are held in the
>same memory location.
>
>So you have two options that I can see, override equals, or pass the
>Strings you want to check for equality into assertEquals. Something
>along the lines of:
>
>1.) assertEquals(expView.stringToTest, retView.stringToTest);
>
>2.) public void equals(Object object) {
> if (object instanceof View) {
> return ((View)object).stringToTest.equals(this.stringToTest);
> }
> return false;
> }
>
>--
>Erik Meade emeade@...
>Senior Consultant Object Mentor, Inc.
>http://www.junit.org
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Luis [mailto:lrb3000@...]
> > Sent: Wednesday, February 07, 2001 1:46 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] Correct Use of assertEquals()
> >
> >
> > Hey everyone,
> >
> > I am using assertEquals() to compare the values of strings within two
> > objects.
> >
> > The syntax I'm using is:
> > assertEquals(expView, retView);
> >
> > The test fails with the message:
> >
> > junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
> > expected:<com.reta.af.common.viewfinder.View@11978b> but
> > was:<com.reta.af.common.viewfinder.View@742ad0>
> >
> > The problem is that the values of the two objects are the exactly the
> > same.
> >
> > Should I be using a different method to compare the values within the
> > objects? Or am I using this method incorrectly.
> >
> > Thanks for any help,
> > Luis
> >
> >
> >
> > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> > junit-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
> >
